sub_topic: Modeling the spread of infectious diseases using differential equations
message_1: A city has a population of 100,000 people. An infectious disease is spreading in the city and is expected to infect 10% of the population in the first week. The rate at which infected people recover is 20% per week. Using a differential equation model, calculate how many people are infected after 4 weeks.
message_2:
To model this situation, we can use the following differential equation:

dI/dt = rI - cI

where I is the number of infected people, r is the infection rate, and c is the recovery rate.

In this case, r = 0.1 (10% infection rate) and c = 0.2 (20% recovery rate).

First, we need to find the initial number of infected people after the first week:

I(0) = 100,000 * 0.1 = 10,000

Now, we can solve the differential equation:

dI/dt = 0.1I - 0.2I
dI/dt = -0.1I

Separating variables and integrating:

∫(1/I) dI = ∫(-0.1) dt
ln(I) = -0.1t + C

To find the constant C, we can use the initial condition I(0) = 10,000:

ln(10,000) = -0.1(0) + C
C = ln(10,000)

Now we can write the general solution:

ln(I) = -0.1t + ln(10,000)
I(t) = e^(-0.1t + ln(10,000))

To find the number of infected people after 4 weeks, we can plug in t = 4:

I(4) = e^(-0.1(4) + ln(10,000))
I(4) = e^(-0.4 + ln(10,000))
I(4) = e^(ln(10,000) - 0.4)
I(4) = 10,000 * e^(-0.4)

I(4) ≈ 10,000 * 0.6703
I(4) ≈ 6,703

After 4 weeks, approximately 6,703 people are infected in the city.
